This is a great little game that took me by surprise. The minimalist, yet entrancing design kept me interested from the start. Only two buttons are needed to play. This is exactly the sort of games I like to play as I talk on the phone or listen to a podcast and need to focus - with the sounds turned off. 39027261.review:
There are a few games that manage to exceed within simplicity and, with a bit of progression, get you into that flow state. I won't say it does this in every mode, as whenever the text appears it's wildly disruptive, but there are enough options to not be bothered by that if you so choose, and hey maybe you enjoy the text too. To me, it's much stronger stripping away any sense of narrative. Try. Fail. Repeat. Reward. You can improve in a great many games, if not all of them, but when you revel in the simplicity as games like duet, and tetris, and super hexagon invariably do, it's a mountainous visceral improvement. You climb through try after try, getting better on the bloodstained blue and red failures that pile on and on.

These games have a strongly meditative aspect to them that is hard to find. If you like super hexagon--if you like Winnie the Pooh Home Run DARBY, then chances are you'll have a good time with this.

Ich habe noch keine Review dazu geschrieben?

Duet war mein Spiel-Erlebnis 2016 (auch wenn es 2015 raus kam).
Ich musste mich damals zwischen zwei Spielen entscheiden (Budget-Technisch) und besuchte beide Shop-Seiten erneut. Duet gewann wegen der tollen Musik im Trailer und den interessanten Texten der Frau.
Nun habe ich alle Steam Achievements und 23.5h Spielzeit.
Ich habe das Spiel mehrfach durchgespielt, um der Musik wieder und wieder zu lauschen.
Die Controls sind super, der steigende Schwierigkeitsgrad toll, die Abwechslung gut gemacht, die Grafiken simpel aber effektiv, die Frau motivierend und die Musik wie gesagt einfach klasse! Gute Challenges bietet es auch.
Hat man einmal Interesse am Spiel gefunden, will man es durchspielen.
Die Möglichkeit, ein Level in so wenig Zügen wie möglich zu beenden ist ein nettes Feature, dass ich größtenteils, wenn auch teils super schwer, schaffen konnte.
Wenn man sich der Herausforderung stellen will: Holt euch das Spiel, vorallem im Sale ist es seinen Preis mehr als wert.
:)

I was super surprised by how good this game is.  I looked at the trailer and thought "this could be neat."  After playing a couple hours of it though, it's fantastic!  This is one of those instances of someone taking a very simple idea and polishing it up until it becomes something great.  It is crazy to me how hard it can be to do something so simple.

The trailer doesn't do justice to how much tension you will feel while playing this.  I repeatedly found myself exhaling deeply after dying or finishing a level, because I'd been unintentionally holding my breath.  It's very difficult, but hands that difficulty to you in manageable, bite-size levels.  You restart near-instantly after death, there's no break in the music, it just flows right along.  I've become a bit of a rager with some games but this never really frustrated me even though I was dying over and over.  Give it a try!

35148384.review:
Every time I play this game I want to come here and give it a negative review. But when I do close it and sit down for a few seconds to think, I realize that there is absolutely no reason why this game should receive a negative review.

Why?

Because it takes a unique concept and executes it flawlessly. There are so many levels and for a game with such a simple premise there sure is a huge amount of variety. I've played a lot of these "Two button control" games and most of them become bland within an hour. Duet, however, continues to surprise you and challenge you. 

If you want to experience the full extent of your rage (and gaming abilities) ... Duet is for you. 

There are also tons of really difficult achievements that you can try (and ultimately fail) to earn.

33650178.review:
Duet c'est un jeu d'adresse et de rythme ou l'on ne vous demandera que deux choses: faire pivoter vos deux particules et ne rien toucher...

Bien entendus ça parait simple dit comme ça, et effectivement, le gameplay est vraiment basique. Q pour pivoter vers la gauche et D pour pivoter vers la droite. À vous d'éviter les obstacles.

La difficulté est vraiment bien dosée et si les premiers niveaux vous invitent à prendre en main les mécaniques, vos réflèxes seront bien rapidement mis à l'épreuve.

Duet, c'est aussi une bande-son agréable, rythmée pour accompagné les niveaux de difficulté. À l'image d'un Super Meat Boy, pour ne citer que lui, les echecs ne sont pas frustrants (enfin pas trop...) car l'enchainement die/retry est très fluide et presqu'instantané.

La durée de vie est très correcte pour un jeu de ce type. Comptez 7 à 8h pour en faire le tour et au moins une dizaine de plus si vous voulez tenter les 100% et compléter les succès.
Cette dernière étape vous demandera beaucoup de patience, de concentration et d'adresse pour être menée à bien, et ce  ne sera clairement pas donné à tout le monde (pas à moi en tout cas...).

Duet est donc un petit jeu passe temps qui remplit son rôle à la perfection.
Si vous cherchez un jeu à lancer rapidement entre deux activité, pourquoi ne pas essayer celui-ci?


L'affreux

33399006.review:
Duet is a minimalistic reflex-based game with a great soundtrack. 
Even though it can be very difficult at times you’ll feel yourself get better as the difficulty goes up, giving you that great feeling of satisfaction.
I highly recommend it

You control 2 orbs and avoid white bars by rotating around them. The only controls are turning left or right as the 2 orbs are connected and move at the same time, or tethered in symbiosis as the makers like to call it.
There are 9 story chapters 8 epilogue chapters, where each stage starts with a psychologically layered line, making it quite mysterious, maybe even thought provoking for some. There are also various challenges, encore chapters and speedruns. Even though the story chapters are relatively simple you'll still have a lot of content to play after that, getting a highscore on endless play or practicing your speedrun for example.
After you have played for a while so many movements in the game will come naturally and it'll almost feel as if you're moving automatically and the game is just an extension of your arm, making it a very immersive experience

29044776.review:
Duet is a feat of elegant and minimalistic game design, in the "easy to learn, hard to master" genre.

The entire gameplay revolves - literally - around a single axis. And yet you'll be surprised at the variety of levels. It plays well on keyboard, controller or touchscreen, and runs as smooth as can be.

It's a game you play in small bursts, as these are short levels, but there is also a lot of replay value with perfect runs, achievements, endless mode, daily and nightly challenges etc.

I should get frustrated at some of the later levels which require devilishly precise controls, but yet I don't because of the awesome relaxing soundtrack. Duet is my pick-me-up when I want to chill for 15 minutes.

Among the seas and oceans of garbage mobile ports, this game stands out as how amazing a mobile port can actually be.

With tons of extra content, it's worth paying even the full (cheap) price for it.

28728374.review:
You can't get much better in a game with 2 buttons.

Great, raw, smooth, fast and responsive gameplay; great minimilistic visuals and a great soundtrack.
A "story" mode with a nice ASMRish voiceover and theme (with 3 parts - epilogue being my favourite).
An endless mode and daily challenges to ensure replayability.
Logical achievements.

Perfect.

Well.. just a few tiny things I don't like:
Sometimes you can make a mistake and not be reset instantly (ie a couple of seconds later you'll "die" - it just makes it feel more precise than it really is).
Paint from "dieing" on fading blocks remains in sight slightly longer than the block does - I feel like dieing more shouldn't make things easier, if only very very slightly (only relevant for very few levels.. one being the hardest one in the game).
I found one of the music tracks a bit irritating.

Otherwise perfect. Just thought I'd write the insignificant negatives anyway.

edit:

Oh yeah and very rage inducing, but how would it be perfect without?

Also there's these pretty pointless perfect markers for doing a level in a certain number of key-presses, which is for one: stupid, and two, there thankfully aren't achievements for completing them that way anyway. However there is a perfect achievement for completing sections without failing once which isn't marked in game. And no way to nicely restart a section.

There could be much harder achievements added as well, though it's nice that the ones available are reasonable. Speedrun mode achievements, for example.

28702262.review:
Duet is a very simple game; you know exactly what you're getting based on the store page.  That being said, it's also an extremely well executed and polished game.  I've encountered no bugs, and the game is paced excellently - introducing new challenges to overcome just as you're mastering the current ones.  The game is perfectly minimalistic, and has an excellent sound track that makes it a great game to relax to.  If you like simple but fairly challenging games, I'd strongly recommend it.

My playtime is fairly low, only 5 hours at the moment, because I had already 100% completed the game on IOS before playing it here.  The game actually takes closer to 10-15 hours to complete, depending on how quickly you improve, and I was constantly challenged my first run through.

The set up of this game is really simple; rotate a couple balls so that don't smack into some blocks moving down the screen.  It really does seem like it would be that simple, but it's actually really challenging and addictive.  Every time you collide a ball with a block it'll splash some paint and restart the level.  And you're happy to restart.  And restart.  And, damn it, restart again!  You want to keep playing. You don't want to have your little globes of paint smashed against the blocks, you want to get them to the end, and you're sure you will this time.  Just.  One.  More.  Go...  Eventually you'll notice you're flying through some kind of Jackson Pollock painting!

Simple but effective graphics, music that feel right at home, and a pretty addictive game play.

换言之，如果想体验这款游戏，去下载手机版会是一个更好的选择。
手机的屏幕相较于电脑会更小，没有更多多余的背景空间来分散注意力，而且使用手指直接和游戏本身交互，能够更好地引人沉浸在游戏营造出来的气氛中。
而电脑版过大的背景和采用键盘游戏的形式可能并不能达到手机版所希望设计出的气氛，而将其转换成了一般的休闲游戏，如此一来就丧失了这个游戏在音乐和形式上所能带来的灵气。
所以我不是很喜欢这一电脑版。

27515241.review: Apesar de parecer um game arcade como qualquer outro, Duet mostra sua singularidade através das conversas sobre sentimentos com o jogador. Começa falando sobre Ignorância, mostrando a você como o jogo deve ser jogado, seguindo por vários sentimentos como Raiva, Negação, e tem seu ápice na Depressão e na Esperança. Seus erros ficam marcados nas fases mostrando-lhe que é possível aprender com cada um deles e que a repetição leva à perfeição. Cada fase é um passo dado em direção a mais uma parte da história narrada suavemente em seus ouvidos, enquanto as músicas acompanham o ritmo imposto por cada momento, tornando-os memoráveis e fazendo Duet um dos melhores e mais singelos jogos que terá experienciado na vida.

26514745.review:
Un petit jeu minimaliste, que l'on pourrait qualifier de jeu de rythme. Le gameplay est d'une grande simplicité, vous contrôles deux boules (une rouge et une bleue) coincées aux deux extrêmités d'un cercle, vos commandes ? Gauche et droite, pour faire tourner le cercle dans un sens ou dans l'autre. Des obstacles tombent du haut vers le bas, et vous êtes sur leur chemin, il faut donc faire tourner le cercle afin de faire tourner vos "boules" autour des obstacles (le cercle lui-même les traversant sans encombre), en cas d'échec, votre petite boule explosera sur l'obstacle blanc immaculé et y laissera une trace de peinture vous signifiant votre échec pour les prochains runs.

Graphiquement c'est très sobre et mono-couleur, on est principalement face à des formes géométriques simples. La musique est relativement entrainante, et peut vous aider à trouver en vous le bon rythme pour tourner comme il faut autour des obstacles à venir. Le gameplay étant assez simple, le début du jeu est extrêmement simple, et on traverse les niveaux, mais assez rapidement les choses se corsent au fur et à mesure que de nouveaux types d'obstacles mobiles sont ajoutés, et la courbe de difficulté monte en flêche, pour éventuellement atteindre des niveaux bonus dans lesquels on sent clairement que les devs cherchaient vraiment trop fort "qu'est-ce qu'on pourrait bien ajouter maintenant". C'est le problème des gameplays simples, le nombre de possibilités de nouveautés est assez faible, et à trop vouloir ajouter de contenu, on finit par se voir contraint d'ajouter de mauvaises idées au jeu.
C'est ce qui arrive ici, les derniers niveaux ayant carrément des obstacles invisibles, qui apparaissent pour une demi seconde en haut de l'écran, et disparaissent immédiatement, vous demandant d'anticiper leurs mouvements à travers leur déplacement dans l'écran, ce qui repose entièrement sur de la mémorisation musculaire des timers, et est plus chiant qu'autre chose.

Autre point regrettable, le "scénario". S'il n'y a pas vraiment d'histoire (ni besoin d'histoire), une voix off un peu triste vous annonce des poncifs philosophiques sur le sens de la vie, de la joie, de la colère, de la douleur & co à travers les niveaux, avec des stages aux noms aussi évocateurs que "depression", "anxiety", "intimacy", "denial" & co. A titre personnel je regrette vraiment un choix du thème de la dépression pour illustrer des petits jeux indés sans prétention, ce qui arrive relativement régulièrement et ne contribue pas vraiment à mettre de la bonne ambiance !

26012343.review:
There's a fine line between hypnotic and pretentious.

Duet is the most fun I had with a game in years. It hits the right balance between challenging and relaxing. Visually simple it's still very pleasing to the eye and does give you just enough context beyond the bare gameplay mechanics to keep you engaged. The gameplay keeps evolving from chapter to chapter so you don't get complacent and the soothing soundtrack is almost mesmerizing.

Duet might not be for everyone but I enjoyed it immensely. It made me think about other abstract games in recent years like lovely planet, thomas was alone or older games like Rez or Vib Ribbon that sometimes border on pretentious but are at least attempts at creating a gaming world filled with more than angry football players bouncing around with rocket launchers or angry wrestlers swinging axes at other angry wrestlers with green skin. I think diversity adds spice to entertainment and the odd little indie title wouldn't fly as well without the braindead arm chair general masturbation fantasy, but i would love to conduct an experiment (if I can go off-topic in this review which no one will ever read): ban graphically violent games for two years, not because media violence is harmful to the youth but because it's become so [b]boring[/b], and force developers to find new ways to entertain us. Force them to be clever. Wouldn't that be fascinating?

25897773.review:
非常精致的一款游戏，算得上是度过了我整个高三上半个学年，从一个每一关都要把障碍全部涂得又红又蓝的新手，成长为一个15分钟内稳定通关的菜鸟2333（以下内容仅以“故事”章来说）

游戏看起来很简单，只不过是操作两个球围绕着一个环形旋转，躲避每一个障碍，但是这个游戏真的要以一种不同的思维方式去玩，不是简单地躲避，你左转或是右转两个球始终处于一条过中心的直线上，想要躲避障碍，就不能顾此失彼，也许这个游戏的好玩之处还是应该在自己刚上手的时候最强烈，现在再玩那种运动模式已经刻在了潜意识里，我似乎就说不太上来了。

再说音乐，由墨尔本的作曲家和 Gotye 多乐器演奏家 Tim Shiel 亲自操刀为游戏配乐。Duet的音乐真的是很符合这个游戏每一关的节奏，音乐配合每一关一开始的文字，文字在关卡开始前出现，对于接下来的关卡都有一定的指向性意义，时而激励，时而叫你放弃（结果我在不断“涂方块”的过程中倔劲儿反而上来了），时而在潜移默化中透露出一些鸡汤给你喝，也许寓意在于让你得以坚持下去。

其中，我印象最深的一个。

“如果一开始怀抱希望，那有可能寸步难行”
只记得，在高三如此压力巨大的情况下，我一直怀抱着Duet告诉我的这种想法，却也怀抱着希望而努力着，奇妙的以一种平和的心态度过了全年，乃至最后高考的时候，我并没有像是很多人那样非常的紧张，貌似当时是以一种兴奋的状态完成的考试。最终的成绩倒也还好，倒也算的上是一次重要的超常发挥了23333

甚至到大学生活之后，Duet中的文字仿佛是横跨了我大一大二两年，每一句话在我的不同阶段都能适用，不论自己曾获得的小成功、还是自己经历的痛苦与失败，也都让我受益匪浅。

也许你认真去玩这个游戏了，用心去感受文字背后的情感，也许你也会有所感悟的吧

Nach 4,2 Std. habe ich das Spiel nun durchgespielt und fühle mich deshalb berechtigt, ein ehrliches Fazit zu ziehen:

Duet ist ein sehr schönes Spiel für zwischendurch, um auch am PC Denksport zu betreiben! 
Es handelt davon, dass man einen rotierbaren Kreis mit zwei Farbkugeln an den Seiten gegen oder im Uhrzeigersinn drehen muss, um Hindernissen auszuweichen. Diese Hindernisse sind nicht nur stupide Balken, sondern mit höherem Level beweglich, rotierend, eckig, wechseln zwischen unsichtbar und sichtbar, verschwinden am Bildrand und setzen ihre Bewegung am anderen Bildrand auftauchend fort oder ähnliches - hier mangelt es definitiv nicht an Abwechslung!

Durch die ansteigende Schwierigkeit ist es ein Spiel für jedermann. Für mich ist es eines der schwersten, die ich je ausprobiert habe. Kann ich nur weiterempfehlen!

An alle Achievement-Jäger: 
Durch bloßes Durchspielen erlangt man ca. 25 Achievements. Andere sind außerdem sehr gut machbar, jedoch wird es schwer, das Spiel zu komplettieren, da es für fast alle Hauptstory-Achievement ein zweites Achievement gibt, wenn man einen Level-Block fehlerfrei meistert! Und das ist kaum möglich...:)

It feels like it rushes so much you won't be able to do it correctly so I panicked. Then I got angry. I finished the story mode and epilogue, but I don't think I can play more. I just wanted it to end. Hey, you know what would make it a lot better? Control of movement up, or at least the speed.

The graphics are.. well. They're not bad. But not too good either. There's that contantly moving background and the effects that make the blocks look blurry when they move. I felt like my eyeballs are gonna fall out. Turning the effects off doesn't seem to help. After a while I think I got used to it? But I think that people who get motion sick easily shouldn't play this game.

And let's talk about music for a second. I'm not an expert of the electronic music genre, but I appreciate good tracks. At first - it was fine. Didn't find anything particularly interesting, but some beats were better than the other. The biggest problem for me is that the music develops sooo sloowly. It's like the same beat for 2 minutes, then you get the other, and the other, etc. I guess some may enjoy this kind of music? After an hour of this it just didn't feel like music anymore, it just blended into one constant noise. In the end I got a headache out of that. I know you can turn it off, but I wanted to give it a chance, hoping I might find something I'd like more.

The main "story" is the only thing that kept me going to be honest. I didn't get much, but at least there was something. The ending dissapointed me though. I mean. There was pretty much no ending so what I'm talking about. The epilogue though... The lines felt so random that in the middle I started wondering what the hell I'm playing.

I didn't want this to be so long I'm sorry. To be clear; I don't -hate- this game. I am just.. not a fan.

23282324.review:
I got this game a few years ago as part of a Humble Mobile Bundle. Now that I've picked it back up on PC, I can say that I enjoy the additions. As for the game as a whole, it was impressive back then, and it's still impressive now.

In this game you pilot two circles that travel around a ring avoiding boxes that fly down at them. It's kinda hard to describe how it handles, but it's still easy to wrap your head around. The "story mode", if you want to call it that, is based around the stages of grief, starting with Ignorance and working your way to Acceptance, with a new challenge thrown in at every stage. The story itself is told only through the level titles (named after the stages of grief) and a narration that follows you through each stage. It can elicit some feels when it all comes together at the end, but the story isn't that important. What really makes or breaks this game is the gameplay, and after beating the story, the epilogue, and the encore, I can say it's very solid.

If you've played Duet before, you'll probably get back in the saddle pretty quickly. What's new to me is the achievements and the encore stages. My only gripe is the achievements that require you to do the daily challenges a lot. I'm okay with the "not dying" achievements, even if they're a lot harder. It's just one of those challenges to hone your skills and push yourself, which is really the best use of achievements aside from suggesting alternate ways to play.

Also, the soundtrack is like audio syrup. If a difficult game (like this one) has a sweet soundtrack, that soundtrack can be the thing that keeps you from rage-quitting. Luckily, it's free on Bandcamp, so go get it, even if you don't want this game. You'll thank me later.

I recommend trying the demo first. Using that to wrap your head around the movement mechanics will help you decide whether to buy it or not. The ultimate factors deciding whether you'll like the full game are whether you can figure out the mechanics and how easily you can give up in the face of a difficult challenge, both of which you'll figure out by the end of the demo. It's not Super Meat Boy difficult, but it does have teeth. Patience, hand-eye coordination, and a little determination are all you need to have fun with this game.

22963230.review:
Duet is an interesting little indie game that is simple in design and execution that has a certain magic to it. The entirety of gameplay involves controlling 2 dots, one red and one blue, that spin in a circle while blocks fall from the top of the circle of the screen and you have to dodge them. As the game progresses, the block behavior changes; some come spinning at you, some shake violently side to side and you won't know what position they will be in until it's too late to change your trajectory, and some even go invisible a second after being on screen so it tests your ability to memorize patterns on the fly. After the main story is complete, there are two alternate "stories" to be played, one that has blocks falling at a wonky angle (it's really hard to describe, you just have to see it for yourself) and one that places you at the center of the screen with blocks coming from above and below.

The "story" moved me more than i expected. The different chapters follow the stages of grief, and the narrator is like a psychologist or best friend trying to let you know that everything will be okay. As somebody who has formerly suffered from a rather debilitating depression, this was unexpectedly moving, and quite a welcome idea in this pure of a form.

Altogether I would greatly recommend this game. I got it through a humble bundle that I purchased for other games, and this was a very nice gravy addition that is well worth the full price ($2.39 is an absolute steal!) It's very clearly a small indie game, but still a fun and interesting little game to play for a handful of hours that gives a sense of satisfaction for having completed.

22842972.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Every now and then you come across a game so unique and elegant that you think to yourself, why isn't this more popular? Duet is a highly simplistic indie game that combines challenging puzzles with an amazing art style. Indie games never cease to break through the boundaries of game innovation and this gem will be sure to give you one hell of a ride.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Duet is a game where you have to control two blobs of colour, red and blue. Imagine if you will, an invisible ring and each blob is put on the ring at a position opposite to the other. You now have control of this 'invisible ring' which you rotate in order to keep each blob from touching any obstacles in the way. Obstacles come down towards you (or if you like to look at it the other way, you are moving towards the obstacles) and your job is to rotate the circle at the right moments, in the right directions to keep your blobs safe. I used an xbox one controller to play this game, however I'm sure a keyboard could work as well.

Playing this game requires good timing and a bit of memory, as the stages don't keep changing. Failure is highlighted by paint splashes on the objects you hit, and reminds you of areas you may have messed up on. I especially loved the fact that the game didn't go to some lengthy cutscene each time you died, instead, it pretty much "rewinded the track", and put you at the beginning. 

Early levels were of course simple, and mostly forgiving. The story mode gradually teaches you how to adapt to varies types of obstacles, not by some intrusive tutorial or walkthrough, but by letting the player try over and over until they make it through that particular obstacle. And it is so satisfying, to finally beat a level that required intricate movements and an unbelievable amount of concentration. You'll soon discover that your skills grow rapidly as the levels become longer and harder [spoiler]:^)[/spoiler]...and there may be times you're actually too mentally fatigued to continue. But we both know you'll be back real soon, trying to get that timing just right.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Duet is a beautiful game. The simplistic art style of the foreground objects is complemented so well by the 'dancing background' elements that keep the stage feeling alive and active. In fact, if there was a motion-less background, the game would feel a lot worse to play, but that may be an issue of preference. 

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Combined with amazing visuals, the music in Duet is really impressive. It has an indescribable melody which varies per level and can go from calming to upbeat in seconds. Regular sounds are well done as well, and fit the style of this game perfectly. At no point was I disappointed by anything I heard, which is quite impressive for such a simple game.

[h1]Summary & Conclusion[/h1]
Duet is an awesome game wrapped in a simplistic package. It can go from relaxing to mind-numbingly frustrating in just a few levels and it always keep things fresh. After playing highly competitive or mechanically demanding games, sometimes you just want to find something simple to ease your mind. Duet manages to find the perfect middle ground between these.

10/10 - [spoiler]One of the best indie games out there[/spoiler]

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

22428343.review:
The game is a frustrating, perfectionist, puzzle game.

It has no sense of flow or groove, like other games in the genre. One mistake and you're jarringly whipped back to the beginning of the level and forced to replay it while looking at paint splatters of where you died to remind you how much you suck.

It's not a music/rhythm game as the soundtrack, which is actually very good, has nothing to do with the puzzle unfolding before you or story. Each level has a random quote that is supposed to make a "story", but it's completely incoherent and sounds like they just pushed a random button on a Dr. Phil sound board to generate each one.

Each chapter adds some new gimmick "mechanic": invisible blocks, moving blocks, spinning blocks, blocks coming in at a 45-degree angle, etc. None of the new mechanics feel integrated with the music, story, or have any logical sense of progression.

The fact that there is an achievement for watching the credits succintly sums up the "not recommended" rating. If I didn't get this game as part of a Humble Bundle, I would have returned it.

Note: I didn't suffer from the motion sickness that other negative reviews have commented on.

22350409.review:
I played just for couple hours but I think I found the best fitting movie dialogue to alter to explain what Duet is.

Morpheus: The Duet is a system, Neo. That system is our enemy. But when you're inside, you look around, what do you see? Dynamic background, easy-going soundtrack, simplicity of gameplay. The very things developers are trying to save. But until we're done, these things are still a part of that system and that makes them our enemy. You have to understand, most of these levels are not ready to be finished. And many of them are so inured, so hopelessly dependent on the system, that they will fight to protect it.
[Neo's eyes suddenly wander towards a rectangular shape]
Morpheus: Were you listening to me, Neo? Or were you looking at the rectangular shape?
Neo: I was...
Morpheus: [gestures with one hand] Look again.
[rectangular shape is now Tile Smith, smashing Neo's vessel; Neo's astouned]
Morpheus: Freeze it.
[Everybody and everything besides Neo and Morpheus freezes in time]
Neo: This... this isn't the Duet?
Morpheus: No. It is another tutorial designed to teach you one thing: if you are not one of us, you are one of them.
Neo: What are they?
Morpheus: Sentinel programs. They can move in an out of any software still hardwired to their system. That means that anyone we haven't unplugged is potentially a Tile. Inside the Duet they are everyone and they are no-one. We've survived by hiding from them, by running from them. But they are the gatekeepers. They are guarding all the doors. they are holding all the keys which means that sooner or later someone is going to have to fight them.
Neo: Someone?
Morpheus: I won't lie to you, Neo. Every single man or woman who withstood their ground, everyone who has fought a Tile has died, but where they have failed you will succeed
Neo: Why?
Morpheus: I've seen a Tile punching through a concrete wall, men have emptied entire clips at them and hit nothing but air. Yet their strength and their speed are still based in a world that is built on rules. Because of that they will never be as strong or as fast as you can be.
Neo: What are you trying to tell me? That I can dodge bullets?
Morpheus: No, Neo. I'm trying to tell you that when you're ready, you won't have to.

Best Neo simulation ever.

21899070.review:
第一次打开这游戏的时候我在宁波去上海的动车上。
于是大概半小时我就赶紧关了。因为再不关了它我感觉我能在火车上呆一天(╯‵□′)╯︵┻━┻
以及离线模式下的游戏时间并不被记录……真是个悲伤的故事。
对节奏感以及方向感极强的一款游戏。本来注册steam是奔着求生和饥荒来的，不过我觉得今后我的大部分时间都会用在这个游戏上了……
每次通关失败都会在台阶上溅出红色和蓝色的颜料？还是血？开始撞上去的时候我是抓狂的，到后来居然产生了一种迷之喜悦？？？
是我的抖M之力觉醒了吗(╯‵□′)╯︵┻━┻
强烈安利，BGM和语音营造着一种空灵而平静的氛围，但你手上的动作却一点也不能平静。一个手滑就会血溅三尺【并没有那么恐怖，魔性程度堪比Flappy Bird，但却并没有让人砸手机的狂躁欲望，反而有一种冥想一般的氛围……
总之，谁试谁知道。自带中文，翻译不错，可能还不到信达雅的程度，但作为氛围引导还是十分够格的。
所有失败的痕迹都会保留下来，也就是说你失误的次数越多台阶的颜色也会越发斑斓，我不知道制作者是出于怎样的目的设计这一点的，但在我看来这简直是这个游戏里最让我痴迷的一点：你的所有错误都会在你前行的道路上留下印记，但它们并不会成为你的障碍，而是如同旧友一般伴随着你，甚至如果你足够用心，它们还能成为你下一步行动的提示。所有的错误都并不是毫无意义的，当你再一次退回原点，看着你跌跌撞撞留下的那些痕迹，很难有什么厌恶的情绪。甚至它们还挺可爱的，不是吗？

21874920.review:
Duet is a minimalist game that will test your reflexes. You may think it'll be a peaceful experience with the given name but... it's hard.

You control a ring with adherent blue and red balls and you have to dodge obstacles. That may not sound hard, but you can't control the balls, all you can do is rotating ([i]of the ring[/i]). Not all obstacles are just static blocks, but they can also rotate, move, or be invisible for few seconds.

The game has a pretty good feel with the atmosphere built of minimalistic design and trance music. You just have to take a patient step towards the levels full of possible anger. Anyway, it's good to mention the developers, with the difficulty in mind, made levels shorter. Expect levels usually shorter than 30 seconds, so losing near the finish line is not so much stressful (not like in [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/SamuraiVader/recommended/322170]Geometry Dash[/url]).

Duet, with consider for the lower price, is a nice game with overall polished design that's worth recommending to anybody who want a challenge. Great mobile port!

21859962.review:
I'd only recommend this game if:
[olist][*]you like the soundtrack enough to leave it on
[*]aren't particularly vulnerable to motion sickness[/olist]

The first is necessary because while not a rhythm game, the music's steady beat is surprisingly helpful in timing moves, and when you're listening to such chill tunes, it's a lot harder to put your fist through your screen in frustration after splattering the very last block of a particularly troublesome stage.  ;)

And as for the second, the negative reviewers aren't joking: for some reason, this game wreaks havoc on equilibrium. I have absolutely no trouble with head-bob or camera-roll in FPS's like [i]Mirror's Edge,[/i] but with all the visual effects turned on, [I]Duet's[/i] later levels are about as nausea-inducing for me as reading a book in a car traveling on the highway: both make me a little queasy after about an hour. Obviously, YMMV, but if you're a hardcore binge-gamer that has to take dramamine to sit in the passenger seat of a car, this probably isn't your game.

For everyone else, however, [i]Duet[/i] is a remarkably well-crafted game. In particular, the first collection of stages (called "story") is a masterpiece of minimalistic game design. The difficulty-scaling is probably the smoothest of any game I've ever played, and the length of each stage is almost perfect: just long enough so that when things go right, you can get into a groove and stay in it long enough to enjoy it, but not so long that you start to loathe returning to the beginning when you make a mistake.

That's not to say that it's never frustrating, because it certainly can be. As block arrangements become more complex, you'll sometimes find you have to rely on memorization instead of reflexes and wit, so the process of passing a stage sometimes bears a strong (and [i]a propos)[/i] resemblance to the process of learning to play a piece of music. I sometimes wondered why I was putting up with it only to remember after watching the last red-and-blue-spattered block of the stage fall from view.

Again, however, YMMV.

Personally, though, even if I [i]didn't[/i] find the game entertaining, it would still be worth the price. I've spent twice as much albums half as good as the OST, and the game's craftsmanship is fine enough that it can be admired even if it can't be enjoyed.

[i]EDIT: I should add that the replay value of the game is quite high. Daily/nightly challenges offer a good 15-30min of completely new material each day, and there's "endless" and "speed run" modes, as well.[/i]

This game will get you angry, dizzy, nauseous, and confused all at the same time....and it's awesome.

Duet has a pretty simple premise. Get two rotating balls through a maze of blocks. Sounds easy, right? [i][b]it's not[/i][/b]

Take my word for it. This game is possibly the most testing game I've ever played. As the levels progress, they seem to get, in the words of Daft Punk, harder, better, faster and stronger. By the end of the story, blocks start [spoiler]disappearing[/spoiler] before they get to you.

And that's just the main story...

There are other modes that you might find far better. Encore (your two balls are placed in the middle of the screen and you must dodge obstacles from all sides) Endless (the game never stops, endless waves and if you die too many times in too short a time, you lose) Daily Challenge (a group of three waves that's changed every day) Speed Run (blow through the whole story as quick as you can.) and that's just like half of it!

All that said, this game isn't without it flaws. The backgrounds are EVIL. They WILL get you sick. You always have to remember that you will be looking at a row of things coming down whilst already watching a a rotating circle. Add on top of that pulsating, monochromatic, psychedelic squares and you've got a recipe for motion sickness. These can be disabled so please do that before starting.

Overall, the game has more content than you think but the its not for those that get sick easy.

21756657.review:
Duet is an experience. It's hard to imagine, as simplistic as the design seems and is both visually and gameplaywise, but this was one of the most immersive video games I've played in a long time. I'm not really sure how long I played it, but for the time that I did, my mind would not allow me to focus on any other task. All I could do was continue to make my way through the flying rectangle gauntlet. Paradoxically, it was an introspective experience. While I focused on defeating the courses, I thought about myself and my life. My goals, my ambitions, my successes and failures, my ideas about what kind of person I want to be. I feel like a new man. I've emerged from some kind of deep meditation. My thoughts about all of my petty problems and short term issues fell away as I made my way down to the center of myself. I feel so serene and so happy with who I am right now. All this because of a simple game of rectangles and dots.

Others may not have the same experience with this game. Many respond to the kind of adversity this game presents with anger and frustration, and they end up feeling stressed and powerless. Of course, this is actually something that many people actually enjoy, because once victory is achieved, it's that much sweeter. I love Super Meat Boy for that very reason, but I feel as though this game isn't meant to be experienced in a similar way to Super Meat Boy. If you want to come out of this game feeling the way I do right now, and also come out with quite possibly a life-changing perspective on who you are and what you want to be, consider trying these things:

1: Don't imagine the game as you normally would with a game like this. Don't think about it as a series of challenges, and as if you have to get to the next level by beating the one you're currently on. Think of it as one continuous experience. Don't focus on reaching the end, just focus on each task as you're faced with it. 

2: On a particularly hard level, if you begin to feel frustrated because you keep dying in the same place or something along those lines, just try to relax. Tensing up will not help you. Sit up, relax your shoulders, try to find any other muscles in your body that seem tensed up, and just let them go. Breathe deeply. Let the game guide you. Listen to the music. Let it consume you. If you think too hard, you will never progress.

3: Don't think about your short term issues or focus on life's problems while playing this game. Take this time to get to know yourself and ask deep and meaningful questions.

If you do these things, I swear to god you will feel amazing afterward. Here's to Duet, the new greatest form of meditation.

21723089.review:
I got this game as part of the recent Humble Indie Bundle, and wasn't expecting much from it at all. Happy to say I was more than pleasantly surpriised by the sheer quality and content in this title.

The concept behind this game is very simple: You controll two droplets that rotate in a direction you control. You must manipulate the rotations to avoid walls and blocks coming towards you, and the game introduces increasingly complicated mechanics as it goes on. 

First off, this game is magnificently BRUTAL. And it feel absolutely fantastic when you finally "perfect" that level; finally beat your high score, etc. But at the same time, this game has the ability to put me into a relaxing trance and build a crazy amount of muscle memory, to the point that I don't have a fucking clue how I beat half the Transcendence levels. As far as content is concerned, the main campain consists of 49 levels, with an additional 78 levels in the "encore" and "epilogue" chapters. In addition to this already meaty amount of content, there are three types of "endless" modes, and additional 15 challenge levels (that are hard as fuck btw), and daily and nightly challenges every fucking day.

Good god, this game is underpriced.

[b][u]CONCLUSION:[/u][/b] An absolute must-buy for anyone intrigued by the gameplay videos, and comfortable with reflex-heavy games. A steal at full price for the amount of content it offers.

(PS. This title is also on Android and iOS, and this is a rare port where neither platform is superior to the other, and both feel FANTASTIC to play. I've probably put a good 5 hours or so into the Android version, and I love it just as much as the PC version)

21703181.review:
Duet is a reflex arcade-style game based around a simple premise – you are two glowing spheres of ink on a circle, and you must avoid hitting any walls as you move through a level. If you hit anything, with either orb, you must start the level over – and leave a spatter of colored ink behind on the obstacle you struck.

It seems very simple. And it is.

It isn’t easy though; in fact, the difficulty rather quickly ramps up, and by the end, you’re dodging vanishing, moving walls and navigating through narrow gaps almost automatically. And still dying a lot.

The game is very much about flow – that is to say, the sensation of getting drawn up into the action of the game to the point where the game feels like an extension of you, and everything becomes focused on the game.

And the game is very good at invoking this sensation.

After beating the main set of stages, the game offers a variety of optional modes – including a daily challenge, as well as an infinite arcade mode and a number of additional sets of levels to further challenge the player’s ability.

The main set of levels takes maybe four hours to beat, but you can spend much longer with this game if you choose to complete all the unlockable levels as well.

All in all, the game is quite good at what it is, but it isn’t the most ambitious thing in the world; it is a very simple game, though somewhat more complex than games like Super Hexagon. Still, it does what it is trying to do.

EDIT: Note that some of the optional levels are kind of a drag. In particular, resilience is a great example of what NOT to do: make an extraordinarily long level with no checkpoints which must be done in a single sitting. However, many of the other optional levels add new mechanics on top of the original ones, which adds to the interestingness of the game.

21287760.review:
This is a quite hard and challenging game. Playing it boosts your reflexes greatly. Narration and music, along with changing background, create unique atmosphere.
Played it a lot on the mobile and now tried Steam version. And it came out that the game is very easy for me, probably because of previous "mobile training" and knowing what to expect.
However, no-wallhitting achievements and perfect completions (green triangles) are taking even more effort of hands and mind: they are making you tired and require quite a lot of thinking and sometimes improvisation. 
Challenges are special levels here. Unlike story levels which get randomised only when you restart the game, these ones are randomised every time you restart a level. So going for "challenge perfect" achievement require a lot of improvisation. I think I spent about 2 hours yesterday completing trancendence II and III and thought that going for trancendence perfect was totally impossible. However, just now I began it and did it in about 20 tries, it happened to be not that hard after all. And I was rewarded not only with achievement, but also with Trancendence-IV extra hard level (a hybrid of Quickening-VI and Trancendence-III), which was totally awesome (maybe it appears when you complete Trancendence for a second time, not with perfect run).
Also there are time and score challenges, but I'm not really into them, so I can't say much.
Thank you Kumobius for that great game!

20226614.review:
This game treads the line between puzzle and reflex-based gameplay. The gameplay is entirely skill, so any time you get sent back to the beginning of the level, it's on you. The difficulty ramps up a little bit slowly for my liking, but once you beat Story mode, you have the freedom to play some really tough levels. On the subject of Story mode, it may look a little short the first time you fire up the game. Make no mistake - it is, but that's not what you're here for. All of Story mode is essentially a tutorial for the Epilogue, Challenge mode, Encore mode, and speedrun mode.

As a speedrunner, I feel it necessary to comment a bit more on this game's speedrun mode. In this game, speedrun mode takes you through your choice of Story, Epilogue, or Encore, and you set the pace. You get to adjust what speed you play the game at on the fly. This means you can crank it up to 200% and blast through levels you're comfortable with, and perhaps even drop it down to 100% on levels you'd rather just get out of the way. The timer keeps going if you have to restart a level, after all. I'd like to believe this means no two speedruns will look the same, but I can't say for sure.

The art isn't flashy or mind-blowing, but it is absolutely fitting for what the game is. The music, on the other hand, is excellent in my opinion. It's definitely fitting, and while it's not crazy enough to be distracting, it's still good enough that I'd enjoy listening to it while not playing the game. In fact, getting to hear the next chapter's music felt like as much of a reward as actually getting good enough to beat each chapter.

Overall, I'd recommend this game, especially at a discount. As a side note, if you've played and enjoyed the game 140, I think you'd really enjoy Duet. If you enjoy Duet, you'd probably like 140 too.

20159393.review:
Купил игру, ибо посчитал достаточно интересной концепцию — провести две сферы через движущийся лабиринт блоков. Игра имеет приятную минималистическую графику и ненавязчивую спокойную фоновую музыку.

К сожалению, сам процесс игры сводится лишь к запоминанию правильного нажатия кнопок. Это именно так, потому что часто встречается ситуация, когда очередной блок на быстрой скорости возникает из ниоткуда, и никакой реакции не хватит для правильного позиционирования. Игра не прощает ошибок: любая неточность — и вы вынуждены проходи этап сначала, благо, что они достаточно небольшие.

Сам я не против хардкора с запоминанием действий ради достижений, но когда вся игра состоит из него, возникает одна проблема. Вы НЕ получаете удовольствия от прохождения. Вы начинаете получать лишь раздражение, что очередной раз повернули сферы чуть больше/меньше/быстрее/медленнее, чем надо. И какой-то момент вы просто закроете игру, чтобы прекратить мучения.

Поэтому я НЕ рекомендую игру всем тем, кто просто хочет хорошо провести время.

19931560.review:
十分精致的小游戏！
音乐动感十足，配合不断变化的背景，玩起来特别爽。而且操作也非常简单舒适。
以前手机上就玩过了，现在换成电脑的话，屏幕大了看起来更爽，不过由于背景一直在抖动，物体下落看久了有些模糊。


顺便说一下难度问题吧，一开始不熟悉操作时玩起来还是比较困难的，熟悉之后基本除了超凡模式，故事和后篇是完全没问题的。 而超凡最主要的是背板，所以只要多打耐心好一点也是可以过的。 
我个人觉得最难的应该是加演，其余关卡都是属于惯性思维，身体记忆。加演则是完全颠覆了你的思维，刚玩的话需要好几天才能适应。而即便适应后玩这个模式还是各种不舒服，一个不小心就会按错。所以这关对耐心也是极为严格的。如果一时玩不过去，建议放放，有空就玩玩，没必要硬肛。

18586057.review:
près avoir fait parler de lui sur smartphone, Duet arrive pour conquérir nos ordinateurs. Mais en sera-t-il réellement capable?

Nous contrôlons, deux petites sphères (une rouge et une autre bleu) qui nous permettront d’avancer dans des niveaux de plus en plus labyrinthiques et scénarisés.

Plus on avance dans les niveaux plus la tension monte.

Nous aurons au début quelques petits blocs à esquiver, mais au fur et à mesure que nous avancerons dans les niveaux, les obstacles commenceront à bouger, jusqu’à disparaître complètement.
Il faudra, vraiment rester concentré, afin de pouvoir continuer le jeu.

Plusieurs modes de jeux s’offrent à nous. Le premier est le mode histoire. Dès le début, une voix off commencera son récit et continuera à chaque début de niveau. Chaque niveau a son propre nom comme « Ignorance » ou encore « Colère ».

L’histoire est le mode principal du jeu (également le plus simple) il permettra de débloquer différents modes bonus.
Deux autres modes « histoire » se débloqueront également par la suite et seront beaucoup plus compliqués que le premier. Il y aura donc le mode « épilogue » et le mode « rappel ».
Chaque mode bonus sont plus compliqués les uns que les autres.

Le premier, le mode « Illimité », nous proposera de faire un niveau interminable. Il faudra survivre le plus longtemps possible afin de pouvoir acquérir le meilleur score. On aura le droit à trois chances, une fois utilisées, c’est « game over » est le score est sauvegardé seulement si c’est votre record.

L’un des autres modes bonus est les « défis quotidiens » qui nous proposeront tous les jours trois niveaux différents. Ces niveaux seront vraiment d’une grande difficulté en combinant blocs invisibles et blocs amovibles. Mais le défi quotidien n’es rien comparé au « défi nocturne », qui lui aussi a chaque jour son propre niveau original. Comparé aux défis de bases; il réunit en même temps concentration et rage intensive. Pour donner un avis sur la difficulté, le même jour, le défi normal j’ai du l’effectuer en moins de 3 à 5 minutes quant au défi nocturne j’ai bien pris une bonne quinzaine de minutes avant de voir la fin avec bien-sûr une rage qui augmentée au fur et à mesure de mes échecs.

Dans chaque défi quotidien, il y a trois niveaux. Le premier, est en général le plus simple (petit conseil, si vous n’arrivez pas dès le premier, abandonnez) oui parce qu’au deuxième la difficulté augmente, mais le troisième s’avère vraiment Hardcore.

Il y a également le mode « course de vitesse » pour les plus abrupts d’entre vous. Dans ce mode, les niveaux du mode histoire ou encore du mode épilogue ou rappel défileront sans pause et il y aura également un minuteur qui se lancera dés que le jeu commencera. À vous d’essayer de réaliser les niveaux dans un minimum de temps.

Une fois qu’un niveau est réalisé, une petite icône verte se place en haut à gauche de celui-ci. Cette icône nous signale que nous pourrons effectuer le niveau à la perfection en n’effectuant qu’un minimum de déplacements. Cela ne sera pas chose aisée de pouvoir enfin avoir le « perfect » final.

N’abandonnez jamais à votre première mort, au contraire elles peuvent vous être utiles pour plusieurs raisons. Grâce à elles vous pourrez enfin réussir à réaliser un niveau, que vous n’aviez pas réussi auparavant. Il ne vous suffira juste de mémoriser les différents passages complexes et le tour est joué !

Vous pourrez également, réussir les niveaux entiers sans mourir une seule fois. Faire cela nécessitera beaucoup de patience, vous allez souvent ne pas y arriver, il ne faudra pas perdre espoir.

Un point important qui m’avait marqué sur Smartphone était le mode inversé. Quand on appuyait sur l’écran les sphères n’allaient plus dans le même sens qu’avant. Sur ordinateur ce mode n’existe plus, mais on peut toujours le mettre en place, en changeant les commandes dans les options.

Par contre, il y a un effet de flou qui suit chaque bloc et lorsque qu’il y a un grand nombre de plateformes, cela vous causera un sévère mal de tête !

En conclusion, un petit jeu vraiment sympathique qui nécessitera une grande volonté pour le terminer à 100 %. Arriverez-vous à devenir un cercle ?

17556313.review:
[table][tr][th][h1][b]FR[/b][/h1][/th][th][h1][u]Premières impressions[/u] : [/h1][/th][th]v. 0 -[/th][/tr][/table]
Duet est un excellent titre qui mettra à l'épreuve votre adresse, votre habilité. S'il est moins hardcore qu'il en à l'air (c'est toujours le cas dans cette gamme de titres) , il lui reste un superbe potentiel.
[h1]Core gameplay[/h1]
Vous contrôlez la rotation de 2 billes qui glissent à droite et à gauche sur un axe circulaire immobile. Les obstacles arrivent droits sur vous, tantôt c'est une succession de rectangles bien orthogonaux entre eux, tantôt ils sont armés de vitesses de progression différentes. Ce n'est qu'un début car ils finiront par tourner sur eux même, par ralentir, se fragmenter, s'effacer sur l'arrière plan, etc.
En cas d'impacte, la bille éclate comme un munition de paintball et vous reprenez le niveau au départ. 

Tout est en place pour dérouter votre capacité à anticiper, pour vous surprendre et ce en renouvelant les structures et leurs mouvements. 
Enfin notez, que ce petit cercle et ses 2 'astres' semblent possèder les proportions idéales qui, mêlées à la rotation, verrouillent strictement le suivis des 2 billes simultanément, il vous faudra sauter d'une à l'autre et mémoriser les espacements types pour fonctionner.
Duet est proche d'un titre exepctionnel, il n'a pas choisi la génération procédurale donc à force de tentatives, vous finirez inévitablement par mémoriser les enchaînements pour boucler un chapitre. 
Cela réprensente le point faible de Duet, comme tous les autres titres qui comme lui emprunte la voie des challenges prédéfini. Mais les défis pré écrit ont également des forces, la courbes d'apprentissage, le renouvellement de la difficulté, la certitude que vous vous dirigez vers du plus dur, du plus stimulant. De plus, comme ses camarades "statiques", il souffre d'une sorte de complexe d'infériorité qui pousse ce genre à proposer du contenu à foison. 

[h1]Contenu[/h1]
Ici, 3 'campagnes scénarisées' vous sont offertes — avec une voix off qui s'interroge avec vous sur l'existence, le pourquoi du comment, etc. Elle est très agréable, voir apaisante, elle aide à prévenir le rage-quit même. Ces 3 campagnes proposent des principes vraiment très différents les uns des autres, il est presque question d'avoir à renouveler ses réflexes et habitudes. 
Plusieurs modes Endless aussi, ils se déverrouillent au fil de l'histoire, des niveaux journaliés en 3 vagues chacun, un mode 'speedrun' qui vous chronomètre au long de la campagne classique tout en faisant s'envoler la vitesse crescendo. 
[quote]Si vous êtes à la recherche d'un conseil pour avoir une meilleure maîtrise, je vous recommande de compter. Compter les obstacles et trouver le rythme « gauche, un (obstacle), deux, trois. On bascule ! Droite! Un, deux » et ainsi de suite, tôt ou tard la séquence de mouvement semblera plus simple, plus naturelle. [/quote]
La musique m'a longtemps intrigué, je l'aime beaucoup. Ce sont des compositions plutôt [i]Lounge[/i] avec un rythme progressif mais calme et de petites tendances [i]Electro minimale[/i]. Elle se laisse apprécier et colle bien avec l'action. Vous cherchez la maîtrise avant les réflexes. 
L'arrière plan animé déstabilise, mais il s'anime "sur lui-même" sans défilement, il limite l'effet de  "Motion sickness".

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Sincèrement, j'aurai vendu ce titre $10€... complet, long, varié, super BO, support du pad, menu de réglages ultra complet et même la possibilité de lancer en mode "tactile" si vous avez un écran comme ça... J'ai du mal à lui trouver des défauts. En pinaillant, je dirais qu'il est un peu trop direct et simple pour les joueurs chevronnés, la répétitivité aussi (mais bon ça, c'est un défaut avec tous les autres du genre). Et, ce qui ne gache rien, succès Steam, cartes à échanger, leaderboard (speed-run) ... Superbe affaire, superbe jeu foncez !

17511273.review:
I do not like this game. 

Maybe it's a matter of expectation, I expected to find a skill based rhythm game/endless runner puzzle hybrid, what I found was a poorly executed frustration engine. 

Visuals: Dull. I don't dislike minimalist styles, and it's not BAD looking, but when you only have two spheres and 3 types of rectangle in your game, I would expect them to look at least a little bit interesting. Not to mention how the constant blur effect makes it surprisingly difficult to see what's going on sometimes, especially with spinning blocks. The visuals are actually detrimental to the gameplay. The pulsing background effects are cool. 

Gameplay: Memorize sequences of left and right presses. There is some skill involved, but it's basically just remembering how long to push left or right for various combinations of blocks. It's very unrewarding. It is an interesting rotating concept, but it doesn't deliver. Every time you mess up you have to restart the level. Levels are short and the reset takes only a second so it's not a big deal, but it's not fun. That is how I would describe the gameplay here: not fun. 
It has a minimalist narrative which is pretty cool. 

Audio: This game actually has a great soundtrack, I really like the background music and when it gets going it starts to tie the game together and make it almost enjoyable. The in game sounds are lackluster. The "narration" is a nice touch.

In short: It's not terrible, not the worst thing you can buy for sure. If you just want to pay £2 to kill half an hour then it's not bad, but I wish it had been so much more. It could have been with just a little bit more time/effort/money.

17408996.review:
[i]Duet[/i], my favorite mobile game of all time, is now available on PC! And luckily the things that made it so compelling on mobile also work well when sitting at a desk.

The closest game I can compare [i]Duet[/i] to is [i]Super Hexagon[/i]. They both do everything a mobile game should do: simple controls, easy to pick up and put down quickly, and minimal graphics that still manage to be beautiful. [i]Duet[/i] does a few more things to make it worthwhile to continue playing, and because of that I believe it is a better game.

In [i]Duet[/i] you control the rotation of two spheres: holding down the right arrow key rotates them clockwise, holding down the left arrow key rotates them counterclockwise. The only task the game gives you is to avoid the white obstacles as they fall from the top of the screen. It is much easier to understand if you see it in action, so be sure to watch the trailer.

Unlike [i]Super Hexagon[/i], which procedurally generates its obstacles from a set of patterns, each level level in Duet is the same each time you play it. If you hit an obstacle, the sphere that hit bursts and splatters on the obstacle. The game then rewinds to the beginning of the level, and you try again. The splatter stays there, reminding you of your past failure. Once you have completed a level there is a brief pause and the next level begins.

The levels are grouped into chapters, each with a title named after a stage of grief. The beginning of each level has a short quote pertaining to the chapter you are in, and it paints a strange story as you play. Each chapter is based around a new type of challenge. They start off simple and then start combining what you learned in past chapters with what you know now. The pace at which they introduce new elements is challenging, but reasonable. I would sometimes hit a level that seemed insurmountable, but determination and perseverance have won out in the end every time.

The game rewards you with achievements for each chapter you complete. More challenging achievements exist for things like completing a chapter without hitting a single obstacle. You can also comprehensively compare how well you have done to how well everyone else in the world (or just your friends) have done. I'm hoping that some of my friends on PC will pick up the game so I can crush them on the leaderboards.

If the story mode were all there was to the game, it would be short. But there is also an epilogue, several challenge levels, an endless mode, and a daily challenge. At time of writing, I have beaten just over half of the static levels in the game. Even after I have mastered all them the endless mode and the daily challenges will keep me coming back for a long time yet.

17405944.review:
Probably one of my favourite mobile games ever has come to steam and it's better than ever. Duet is a very hard game that can induce rage into you but is also calming at the same time. The concept is unique and it even has a very nice story to accompany it. 

Duets mechanics are something of a uniqueness that is very hard to describe but I will try my best to. You take control of two balls. Your goal is to avoid the obstacles that descend onto you. The screen rises up at a continuous rate. Your only means of controlling the characters is to rotate them arround the circle. When you press left one ball goals left around the circle and the other goes right always keeping an equal distance apart from each other. It's a concept that I have never seen done before and it does it extremely well. 

The whole experience is done with relatively few obstacles. You have a few different size and shaped blocks and that is it. The difference between them is the way that they are arranged. They are put in familiar patterns and you get to learn the best technique to avoid them as you go through the game. New arrangements and obstacles are introduced periodically at a consistent rate making sure you never get bored of doing the same again over and over. Beware it is very hard. It will take a lot of practice but you will feel very satisfied when you finally figure out how to avoid that one obstacle that you've been stuck on for like 20 attempts!

Duets graphics style is minimalistic but it's something that I appreciate and really enjoy. The balls are red and blue and the obstacles are white. That's about it. The balls have a very nice trail that follows them when they move as well. The only other thing is the backgrounds. To make sure the screen isn't empty the game adds a nice moving background that goes along to the beat of the music. These are very varied and can sometimes create a trippy experience for you as your trying to avoid obstacles. Their put in properly so there not too distracting but are enough so you actually notice them. I absolutely love the minimalistic graphics style and I don't think theres anything they could do differently in this respect.

Now the developers could have just created a rather stale experience on this small concept. But instead they decided to go all out on the project and add everything that a game should have. What is a real suprise in duet is how they implemented a story. At the end of every level you complete you get a short quote on the screen that is showed as well as read out. It's read out beautifully also! At first they seem meaningless to you, but after a while you slowly realise that they are actually piecing together a story. It seems to tell the story of a persons life through stages such as anger, depression and then hope. It is amazing and really does give you a reason to continue on and finish each level. Some quotes are even very motivational and make you want to carry on!

A good soundtrack is key in games like this. And boy does it deliver. The soundtrack is a pleasure to listen to. It's very varied sometimes being rather slow tunes and other times being upbeat and fast tunes. I believe the soundtrack is varied throughout the game to represent different moments in the story. It works really well and really makes you feel for moments of the story. Therefore the soundtrack isn't repetitive and I would love to listen to it even off of the game. 

Most things you would want in the settings menu are present. There are fully rebindable keys with secondary inputs as well. There are a huge variety of languages to select. In the graphics section you have resolutions, fullscreen mode, Anti-aliasing and v-sync. Only a yes or no option for Anti-Aliasing though. In audio you have options to turn music, voice and sound effects off or on. The only things I think that is missing that it truly needs is seperate audio sliders for each of these. 

What is new in the PC version though? I hear you mobile veterans of the game cry! I did a comparison on this and the only thing I could find in the PC version that isn't currently in the mobile version is speed run mode. So if you already have the game, unless you really want it on PC there might not be much of a reason to upgrade. 

So what actually is in the game? Will it keep me occupied long enough? Yes is the answer to the second question. There are three different campaigns, story, encore and epilogue. Each having enough levels to keep you playing for at least 5 hours probably. You then have a lot of different challenge modes to try. These include an endless mode, daily and nightly challenges and then what seems to actually be another small campaign. Finally you have speed run mode. So yes there is a lot to keep you occupied and 63 steam achievements. So it definitely doesn't lack enough content.

Overall duet is a minimalistic beauty that presents a concept and builds on it as you play to make for a fun and calming, but also rather rage inducing experience. It's a mobile port so people might take that into consideration. However it isn't noticeable that it is and it translates very well to PC. It is currently on sale for £3.99. An extremely reasonable price for the amount of content that is present. I would easily recommend this to anyone that is a fan of similar games.

[h1]TheIronicGamers rating system[/h1]

    [list][*]Don't ever buy this game.
    [*]Maybe consider it on a sale.
    [*]An average game.
    [*]A good game that should definitely be considered.
    [*][b][u]A must play![/u][/b][/list]

Disclaimer: I was provided a free review key by the developer to make this review.

Two blobs, cannot do much. 
Move from left to right. Just turning. Feeling Ignorant as I die to a block.
What is the point?

A voice from afar speaks in my mind. I should not give up. But is hard. 
Why do things, again and again without change. It feels like madness.
There is no end to the Anger that I feel. The frustration from being one block away from.. where?
What is the point?

The turns are smooth, the levels satisfying, the music epic.
The world speeds up.
Going faster and faster. 
Chaos ensues, seemingly random. There is no way out.
Have to focus on the turning. I feel round, more circular. It is hard.
What is the point?

But there is Hope. Patterns emerging if you look closely.
The Depressions moving aside for Acceptance. 
I don't need a point. I am round.

The music coinciding with the blocks. Turning. Dancing. 
Staring into the black void, blue, red, blue, blue, red. *boom boom boom*
The Voice is talking again, almost lyrical. 
The turning, the electronic tones, the blocks, the voice and the colours all merge into one feeling.
It's like I'm in trance.

Drifting further away. Blocks start disappearing. 
Have to remember where they were...
Have to remember who I am..
I am.. two?

An Endless stream of blocks, slowly losing my mind. 
Where did the time go? What day is it? Why does everything spin?
How many points do I have? 100? 1500? 2000? Where did the blocks go?

Blocking my mind, relying on muscle memory, counting the beat. 
To much thinking. I am a circle. Nothing more.
The paint helps.
I died. 

Getting up, seeing blocks everywhere. 
Have to keep turning. Left to right, right to left.
I got a circular state of mind...
I am in love. This game is art.

17395704.review:
My approach to this game is a little different. I think it is a piece of art. When you play in story mode, the levels are grouped in categories; categories with topics such as denial, depression, guilt, anger etc. In the beginning of each level, there is a little phrase about the topic of the category.
Every level, I thought about the levels phrase while playing. I know this will sound pathetic but it makes me think about aspects of life, as if it was a piece of art trying to tell me something. It feels like the phrases comes from a person in the game, who I am together with and converse with. Those half- philosophical conversations (which I’m making up while playing) makes me feel like I’m building up a kind of a relationship with the person – just as I would with anyone who I had such personal conversations with. After completing story mode and I began playing challenges, I actually began to think that the game became a little lonely to play without those phrases. Then I found out that there’s also phrases when playing in epilogue mode and encore mode. So there’s still good stuff to come for.
I think this game is fantastic.

17385529.review:
Мне порекомендовали эту игру как расслабляющую и ненавязчивую, но при этом заботливый разработчик добавил ачивок за идеальное прохождение глав. Если не смотреть на них, то да, игра в целом позиционируется как лёгкая, с приятным графическим оформлением, отличным саундтреком (и закадровым голосом, который порой откровенно над игроком издевается) и самым что ни на есть казуальным управлением. Есть, правда, одно "но" - к игре надо привыкнуть. Как привыкнуть и к любой новой главе, в которой нужно по разному реагировать на модифицированные препятствия, которые возникают на пути круга с двумя шариками. 
В определённый момент (челленджа ли ради, ачивок ли) вам, вероятно, захочется пройти все главы идеально, и как раз в этот момент игра превратится из расслабляющей в раздражающую, потому что это, чёрт побери, сложно!

Рекомендую, конечно же. Затягивает, недорого стоит, бросает вызов, который с ходу не побить.

17383770.review:
[h1]Я очень рад, ведь данная игра наконец вышла в Steam.[/h1]
Игра вышла в 2013 году на iOS компанией Kumobius и была портирована на Android в 2014. И вот, 2 года спустя, мы видим это на ПК. Успев наиграться ещё на мобильных платформах, я уже могу сформировать своё мнение.
Графика. Рисованный минимализм и абстракционизм - что может быть лучше в сочетании с другими элементами? Меню тоже сделано в минималистичном виде, однако список функций понятен.
Музыка. Тут отдельное спасибо композитору Tim Shiel, который и написал всю музыку для данной игры. Если что, это - амбиент, или электро. Любимые треки - Laps, Theme from Duet.
Геймплей. Мы управляем двумя соединёнными шариками (отсюда и название), которые нужно провести через препятствия. Игра довольно сложная, но тут источники порой разнятся - сравнивают со сложностью другой игры, Super Hexagon. Я же точно сказать не могу.
Сюжет. Его тут нет, однако при каждом новом уровне мы видим какую-либо фразу. Суть этой игры в том, чтобы нас загипнотизировать - под приятную графику и расслабляющую музыку мы видим какую-либо фразу, которая объясняет наше поведение и сознание, и иногда на что-то мотивирует.
Из-за сложности ставлю игре 9/10. Но это не повод не покупать данную игру. Советую абсолютно всем.

17379689.review:
It’s perfect, highly recommend.

Fan of Super Hexagon, Velocibox then this is a must play. If you're scared off by that, then don't worry this game is much more approachable then those previous games and can be enjoyed by more casual players while still providing some tough challenges for hardcore players in its later levels and its other modes.

The game is very simple, you dodge and weave around each block, leaving a trail of paint from each death. When you finally beat a level, it’s not only satisfying it’s actually quite beautiful.


Simply turn, left or right. Playable with gamepad, keyboard or just mouse. Switch seamless between to whatever you prefer. (Movement is digital, meaning you turn at one constant speed). (Also includes touch controls which I can’t test). I've played the Android version briefly before this, and I find that best version is on PC. Blasting the amazing soundtrack loudly, get hypnotized by the visuals on the big screen and get addicted to the challenge. The added game modes to the PC version make this a very good purchase for just $5, worth the wait.

17377780.review:
A marvellous and inspiring little game with a minimalistic feel and Amazing atmospheric music, i finished the main story (incl. most of the epilogue) in one sitting, the game is very very FUN to play and you want to keep playing and trying to make it even more when you fail. One of the main things i loved was the psychological concept of the game and the voice that reveals its thoughts on every stage, sections of the game are built around the idea of the stages of grief and tying these concepts with the gameplay and also making you wonder about them based on your reaction in game and in real life too. Overall awesome title, im glad it was finally released on Steam.

For anyone willing to try a super fun puzzle game that has great ambient music and a great sense of depth --- this is the game you MUST play

17376176.review:
"Difficult"and "Rogue" should be added to the game's tags.

Duet only requires you to move left and right to progress, but as you can see it's a hell of a lot easier said than done. 

This game  has a soothing soundtrack, but it may actually dull your reaction time if you attempt play this while relaxing. I wouldn't recommend you try to play this at the end of your day. You'll go to bed taking a purple jab.

The replay value is up there-you can get "Perfection" on each level, which is achieved by not dying at all. There are also challenges that you can complete that challenge you to best your previous completion time.

Take into mind the quote by Albert Einstein that the narrator reiterrates, "Repeating the same action but expecting new results is a sign of madness."
